title.narrative: Integrated Systems, RACS

description.narrative: Integrated RACS (Palm Oil) is implemented in South Caribean Coast Autonomous Region of Nicaragua to engage industry and producers in the implementation of best practices and increased productivity through an inclusive business model that focuses on diverse production systems. In partnership with CIAT, Ritter Sport, ECOM and 3 producer organizations, we trained 822 cocoa and livestock producers on innovative agroforestry systems. By 2020, 1,365 hectares were brought under climate management practices, and the pilot showed promising results: an income increase by 6% and milk productivity increase of 24.5%. At the cooperative level, cocoa sales increased by 118% compared to 2019. The 2 cocoa cooperatives we work with obtained Rainforest Alliance certification, and we have strengthened them to provide more and better services to their members. We started to develop a business model for these farmer-led "service provision hubs" that is expected to increase access to technical assistance for smallholders in remote areas (e.g. vaccinations and insemination of livestock, to the use of digital tools for harvest estimation, rehabilitation of cocoa areas, cocoa post-harvest and collection, drying facilities, etc.). These hubs will function under a fee-for-service model. Through the PASOS platform (see Advocacy for Change), and in collaboration with FUNIDES and the EcoBusiness Fund, we supported small scale livestock producers that adhere to zero-deforestation production, to improve their access to credit. Feasibility and market studies were carried out for the establishment of cocoa agroforestry systems in their farms, and farmers were trained on the use of the Forest Watch platform to monitor land use changes in livestock farms (one of the key requirements to access credit).

title.narrative: % change in producer or worker income

comment.narrative: 200 producers trained in animal health, silvopostoral system, animal reproduction and farming plan, 62 producers trained in good agricultural practices in cocoa (harvest and post-harvest, cocoa genetics, agroforestry arrangements and chocaletes manufacture. We expect in 2018 they implement good practices to increase productivity and income.

comment.narrative: 30 jobs have been generated directly

title.narrative: % change in producer or worker income

comment.narrative: 356,68 USD / Month (11%) Milk production, production of dairy products, fattening of steers and cocoa have increased

comment.narrative: 414 USD/Month

title.narrative: % volume commodity produced that meets sustainability standards/Good Practices

comment.narrative: 446760 lt of milk / year (increased 21%)

title.narrative: # of companies that meet sustainability standards or Good Practices

comment.narrative: Establishment of pastures improvements (39%), division of paddock (7%), establishment of electric fences (7%), multinutritional block (18%), animal supplementation with mineral salts (25%), animal health management (29%) ), handling of agricultural products (14%), no burning (7%), management of natural regeneration (29%). Cocoa pruning, pest and disease management, soil conservation works, harvest practices. 55 = 30 (15% of cocoa producers comply with 25% of the norm's indicators); 25 (31% of cocoa producers have established good agricultural practices.

title.narrative: # hectares where soil fertility is maintained or improved

comment.narrative: Livestock and cocoa - Agroforestry systems with established cacao, establishment of improved pastures with trees in paddocks, live fences, weed management in both systems

title.narrative: % change in yield or productivity

comment.narrative: Investments in farms require a long term for the recovery of investment. In 2017, the project activities were focus in the established of field schools and demostration plots for the producers capacity building, and as a strategy to motivate the investments of the producers in tne implementation of the practices in 2018.
